name: Buttercream
headline: Buttercream
recipeIngredient: 10 ounces butter, cubed and at room temperature

recipeInstructions.text: In a large mixing bowl, whip the eggs until light and fluffy.

In a small saucepan bring the sugar and the corn syrup to a boil. Lubricate the inside of a metal baster with a small amount of vegetable oil and dispense it completely. Then use this to drizzle the sugar mixture into the mixing bowl with the eggs. The mixer should be on low speed until you finish drizzling in all of the sugar mixture.

Once the entire mixture of the sugar is incorporated, slowly add the butter pieces. Only add more butter when you can no longer see the previously added pieces. It will go fast at first and then slow down. Continue to whip until the mixture is creamy.

Food Network Kitchens suggest caution in consuming raw and lightly-cooked eggs due to the slight risk of Salmonella or other food-borne illness. To reduce this risk, we recommend you use only fresh, properly-refrigerated, clean, grade A or AA eggs with intact shells, and avoid contact between the yolks or whites and the shell.

review.reviewBody:
Five stars for flavor, 2 for difficulty! The directions say... "It will go fast at first and then slow down." What it should say is, don't make any plans. It takes time!
Challenges
1 syrup... I tried to cook it based on the bubbles as stated in the episode. I then transferred it to a pyrex container to pour in the mixer. Failed miserably, started to crystallize immediately. Kept beating the eggs and, remade the syrup, this time using a thermometer to check temp, 238 F. Poured directly from my sauce pan as slow as possible. Had a tablespoon crystallize on the bottom of the whisk. Ran the mixer until sides felt cool. The extra time to remake the syrup helped as It gave extra time to whip up the eggs.
2, Room Temp. I keep my thermo set to 63 F. I feel like my butter was just a little too cold and took even longer too incorporate. It looked awful like others stated, just kept the mixer running and bang it came together.
3, tried to double the recipe... dumb! Took hours!

I've tried this recipe twice now, and it is very difficult.  The 2nd time was better, I got it on my cake at least, and it has good flavor.  I just couldn't get it fluffy enough for my liking.  I will try again.  Like all other reviews, I will beat eggs very very fluffy; boil sugar until large bubbles/240 degrees; drizzle in sugar mixture slowly; beat till bowl cools off; keep beating while adding one piece of butter at a time until all incorporated; and beat some more.  Not sure what else I can do...  Hopefully 3rd time's a charm!

I tried making this recipe a couple of summers ago. Turned to soup. Now that I'm in culinary school and have successfully made italian meringue buttercream I know why it did not work out. It tells you to bring the sugar to a boil then pour it in, but it doesn't not say to what temperature. That is the major flaw. Sugars need to be heated to soft-ball stage or about 240 degrees. Butter needs to be soft when incorporated as well. Follow this and all should be well.

This recipe is actually perfect.  The problem with buttercream is that everything has to be perfect for it to come together.  I made this and my butter must have been a bit on the cold side or my syrup/sugar mixture was not hot enough or my eggs were too cold but the butter didn't incorporate into a smooth mixture.  I had to put the mixture on the stove to warm it up and get the butter bits soft.  Then it came together perfectly, but it's an illustration that everything has to be exactly perfect.

Step 4:  This is the critical step of the recipe.  The butter must be on the cold side and not soft.  One of the ways this can go south is if the butter melts in the egg/sugar mixture.  The butter should be firm but forgiving to the touch.  You are in essence absorbing the solid butter into the sugar egg mixture.  The next critical step is how much butter you need.  In my estimation an additional stick more than what the recipe calls for.  You'll start to see a grainy, oily, mixture.  You just need to soak this up with more solid butter.  Be careful that your pile of butter doesn't get too warm.  The consistency you are looking for is in essence creamy butter.  Using an ice bath would help I've read but I normally take a break and stick the mixing bowl and whisk attachment in the refrigerator for 15-20 minutes.  You can also do this if your butter melts and mixture breaks.  Then crank up the mixer again.  You should eventually wind up with a nice, stable, creamy butter cream.  Voila!
If it looks like soup all you have to do in put a bowl of ice under ur mixer to make it cold then it should thicken up
Doesn't the hot syrup cook the eggs?

This is soooo good.  I actually used the version AB put in his book in which he addressed that many people had difficulty with this recipe and altered it.  Mine also turned into a soup, probably because it was 100 degrees outside and my butter was too soft, but I was able to rescue it by placing it in the fridge for about 20 minutes after i had completely finished the recipe and then beating it for about a minute more after that.  It turned out wonderfully delicious.  I also added about 1lb of strawberries, pureed in the food processor (my sister wanted strawberry frosting for her b-day cake).  It tasted amazing but it was a little watery because of the strawberries, but if you leave it in the fridge it will harden up.  If anyone wants the recipe AB puts in his book that doesn't have it, you can just email me, and i'll gladly give it out to you, but i really suggest you buy the book.  There's a lot of updated recipes in there.
Can someone help me out? Another review said "egg whites" but the recipe calls for EGGS, not whites. Mine is just as yellow as it can be, the secod lump of butter turned it into a soup.

I'm not sure what problem other people are having, but this recipe is amazing.
I've made is 4 times now, and about to make it a 5th. It's fairly easy to do, and the result is nothing soupy or chunky. It's perfect.
All i'm saying is, despite everyone else having problems, This is definitely worth trying at least once.

This is a classic french buttercream that pastry chefs have been using all over the world for a very long time. I own a bakery and this is my preferred style of buttercream. He changed it in his book to a swiss meringue buttercream, not because he was wrong, but because everyone had so much difficulty with the recipe. Both the recipe and the video are correct, as any experienced baker can attest. True buttercream is a skill that, once learned, is a magnificient accompaniment to a cake. You need to work quickly when adding the sugar, as that pasteurizes the eggs. As your mixers may be different, refer to the video for cues. Room temp butter is about 70 degrees, only soft enough to make a slight indent with your finger. DO NOT add butter until the bowl of the mixer is room temp, then add butter as directed. If it gets too soupy, your butter melted. Put it in the refrigerator and mix again until it is smooth.

this receipe sucks the first batch my son made and it was a large bowl of soup. i thought he had done something wrong so we tossed about $10 worth of ingredients out he was trying to do a triple batch. the second batch i made and the same thing happend. i then tried adding powdered sugar to the soup as other reviewers tried 4 1bs to be exact to a 1 and 1/2 receipe and though it got thicker it was still to soft for decorating purposes tasted good if you like and butter and sugar i'll keep the second batch to make cookies or something.

I actually made this recipe the first time and it was so watery that I thought I must have made a mistake some how.  Then I simply added powder sugar and it worked beautifully!  This recipe has a wonderful buttery taste...the powder sugar makes it better to ice with.

I've made this buttercream frosting on several occasions, including my fiance's and our daughter's birthdays and every time it turns out wonderfully. I just made it and once again it's amazing, and this time i even substituted the corn syrup for Molasses, and it still tastes great with a wonderful texture. i'll never eat store bought buttercream again.

I did this recipe exactly as follows, and I combined the syrup and the eggs exactly perfectly and had no problems. This recipe is still a flop. It's far too watery and resembles anything but delicious buttercream frosting. Do not waste your ingredients or time on this.

I'm usually an Alton Brown Fanboy, but this recipe is junk.  I've tried this on four separate occasions, and have ended up with lots of difficult to clean pots and wasted ingredients.  Thank goodness eggs and sugar are cheap.  It's impossible to incorporate the hot syrup into the eggs, it just hardens and drops into the bottom of the mixer where it forms a big gooey ball.  If you incorporate it even slower it sets up in the pan and you are looking forward to a half hour of cleaning sugar syrup out of your pots, baster, mixer bowl, etc.  This recipe is listed as easy and fast, it is neither.  Don't waste your time on this one, frost your cake with something else.

I am usually an Alton fan 100%!  I love his Friendly Pantry Sauce recipe, his recipe for pizza dough...but this one disappointed.  I made it to the "T," and it came out too runny.  I went back to his episode and watched it on YouTube while preparing...my eggs looked the same fluffy white consistency that his did...my syrup looked good...I incorporated the syrup with a baster, and then slowly added the butter bits ("no evidence" between bits).  Still it's too runny.  I'm going to stick it in the fridge and rewhip later.  After all the effort it took to make this recipe, it brought tears to my eyes when it failed.  It tastes like buttercream, but looks like a horrible mess.

I am a frequent backer and usually make one or more deserts per week. The first time I made this I was already a little worried because I had intended to start much earlier but was prevented. I realized I wold not have time to make something else if this flopped. And as if that wasn't bad enough, nether my butter or eggs were at room temperature! Nevertheless I forged on, following the directions almost exactly. I only deviated by poring the hot syrup right from the pot into the eggs, a maneuver I?d mastered form making pecan pies for my grandparents on a regular basis (plus I don't own a turkey baster). I microwaved the butter a little but it was still firm and cool wen I started adding it. It took a while and it was hard to see when there was no more ?physical evidence? left of the pieces I was adding but by the time the last piece went in the buttercream was light, fluffy and delicious. This experience made me comfortable enough to plan on making it again on the day I needed it. This time I was able to set out the eggs and butter in advance, what a disaster! Doing everything as before I ended up with a syrup like consistency. I tried to salvage my liquidus mess by refrigerating it for an hour and then wiping again, which produced a sort of curdled consistency that no amount of whipping could smooth. Conclusion? I will probably make this again using cool butter as I did my first time. I will also do it a couple of days in advance, just in case, and whip it up again when it?s time to use it. I suggest anyone who?s willing to give this recipe a try do the same.

I am a huge fan of Alton Brown and I have been cooking using his methodology for years, I own all of his books, have seen every episode of the first 11 or so seasons, and most others and watch nearly everything else he does. I've been in restaurants since I was eleven, and worked under 4 & 5 star chefs. I am not an amateur cook, but I'm not a chef, but I'm definitely a smashing home cook. I really wanted to try this recipe for awhile, just never had the opportunity to, until recently, and I can say that this is the worst recipe Alton has ever come up with. I read every review on the recipe, hoping to glean some bit of information that would assure me a true final product, but after trying multiple times, I can fully declare that this recipe is absolutely horrible and falls FAR short of Alton's standards for his recipes.

I watched the episode two or three times, and read and re-read the recipe. I followed it EXACTLY, and lo and behold, all I got was a nice bunch of hardened sugar lumps sitting in a frothy mess of eggs. There is no place where you can put the syrup mixture that it doesn't touch some piece of metal. I even used a candy thermometer to assure that I had it at the right temperature and by the time I got to the end of the batch the syrup was not able to be sucked up anymore because it had cooled. It was a huge waste of my money for ingredients, my time, and most importantly it discouraged me from making something special for my girlfriends birthday.

Thanks a lot Alton, you really did the opposite of your intention here of being a so called "Culinary Cartographer" (from ver. 2.0 of I'm Just Here for the Food) and you honestly owe a lot of people an apology and a recipe that actually gives results.

To anyone who wants to try this recipe: DON'T. Its a waste of your money and time, better off trying to figure it out from another recipe or source.

I am sure it was due to an error I made in the preparation of the buttercream but something went funky.  When I boiled the sugar and the corn syrup for the first time I think I burned it so I scraped that batch and tried again.  The second batch I was afraid of burning the mixture so as soon as I saw the bubbles I took it off the stove leaving some melted sugar crystals in the bottom of the saucepan.  Then I added the syrup to the eggs, and no matter what I did some of the syrup stuck to the beater and the mixing bowl forming a very tasty candy, but that was not what I was looking for.  I decided to proceed onward, and thought I would fish the "candy" out before frosting my cake.  So I then began adding my butter and that resulted in a mixture that resembled ricotta cheese.  I haven't given up yet, I am just ending it for the day.  I will defeat this recipe and when I do there will be much rejoicing and I will let you all know how I did it.
This is a TERRIFIC recipe! it just takes a little more patience and planning that Insta-Icing recipes...but so freaking worth it!!

This recipe does indeed work.  While I haven't read every review, I understand one of the biggest problems and feel I have found a simple answer if it hasn't been discussed already.  Follow the recipe preparations up to the point of tempering the eggs by putting the hot syrup into the mixer, instead, temper the eggs into the syrup while it's still on the stove and then pour the mixture into the mixer while on low speed. Pick up the recipe from the butter insertion.  This worked SOOOO much better for me, and the buttercream came out wonderfully.

I just got done making this.  Not only does it taste wonderful, but it is nice and creamy!  This is the first time I have made buttercream frosting like this.  (This morning I made my first with confectioners sugar and that was tasty, too!)  I have never made frosting before today, nor have any experience making candy.  I don't even own a stand mixer!  I made this recipe with my $9 hand mixer.  I don't own a candy thermometer or even know what "soft ball stage" means.  Looked that up on the internet and found that the "right" temperature for soft ball stage is when the syrup forms a ball in COLD water but then looses the shape when you put it in your hand.  Well, I don't know if I was truly at the "soft ball stage" when I added the sugar mixture, it came to a boil and it worked.  I did follow Logan's tips and he is good on his word.  Poured the sugar mixture into the bowl right from the sauce pan, and mixed until the bowl was no longer warm.  At this point I was feeling pretty good and quite happy with my success so far.  All the reviews that said this didn't work, and what do you know, it's working for me!  I don't even know what I am doing!  Then I added the first piece of butter and was like WTF!  Ok, so THIS is what everyone was talking about, but have faith...keep mixing and adding butter.  Never did I get some sort of cottage cheese looking concoction, and soon it started looking creamy.  I used the exact amount in the recipe for everything.  Nothing extra.  It is not too sweet.  I am looking forward to making more and trying out different flavors.

This recipe was so so, but this website is so so great! www.cookwithkim.com

Check out her blog too!

http://therealrefrigeratordoor.blogspot.com

This recipe WILL work as written. I attended culinary school and I can tell you buttercream IS finicky, but completely do-able with patience. To begin with, do as others instructed and whip the egg whites until they are stiff (it helps to warm the whites by setting the mixing bowl on your pan of heating syrup/sugar mixture just until it reaches the same temperature as your hand). Cook the syrup mixture to soft ball stage as others instructed. When you are ready to add the syrup to the egg whites, begin with the mixer on HIGH. Use any method you can to get the syrup mixture combined without it touching the whip attachment or the sides of the bowl. If it does, it will harden there. Keep mixing it until on high until the bottom of the bowl feels the same or cooler than body temperature (this generally takes about 10 minutes, so you can clean up during this process if needed). At this point, you can add any flavorings (vanilla being the obvious choice). Adding flavorings when the mixture is too hot will destroy the flavoring. Once it has reached body temperature, begin adding the butter one piece at a time, making sure the previous piece is incorporated before adding the next. Continue whipping on high until all of the butter is incorporated. If the frosting breaks (begins to look like cottage cheese) keep whipping it, it will fix itself. This is the most indestructible version of buttercream available because you have candied the sugar which adds a LOT of stability. Don?t think Alton has forsaken you if you have failed with this recipe, try again with my tips and I am certain if will work for you.

I had similar issues as others with the butter melting and everything becoming soupy. I added an ice bath to my mixer and mixed for a VERY long time. In the end, the recipe was saved and was quite tasty if i might add. I will do this recipe in the future but I will cool the egg/sugar mixture prior to adding the butter AND I will mix with an ice bath.

Oh, and I am not sure how the 3 minute cook time factored into this. This takes much longer.

If the instructions were better, this would easily be a 5 star recipe.

I just spent the last half-hour doing this recipe with my hand mixer - my feet are sore! That being said, I enjoy a challenge and the flavor is 100% worth the effort. My kitchen was too warm for the icing to settle into its intended consistency, so an ice bath helped bring the icing to the right consistency for frosting a cake (thanks to the comments on the YouTube video for "The Icing Man Commeth" episode). This icing and AB's gold cake recipe are the perfect birthday cake duo!

Hey honey, my birthday's coming... how about a stand mixer? ;-)
This is the best frosting ever!!  Seriously.  Creamy and smooth.  Perfect

I would give this recipe  5 stars for flavor.  I had trouble getting it to firm up enough to use for icing a cake.  I used extra butter (about 2 ounces) made sure my syrup was 240 degrees, beat the eggs indefinitely, and beat and beat and beat the butter into it in my kitchenaid stand mixer.  Is it possible that it should require only 2 eggs or 4 egg yolks?  I have made italian buttercream with meringue (whites only) and it always comes out beautifully so I was not anticipating the problem that I had with the consistency of this icing.  It sure tastes awesome, as long as I keep it refrigerated.  I plan to try it again with one or two less eggs and see what happens.

I want to start by thanking AB, and the many reviewers that took the time to post the advice necessary to make this work. I've attempted buttercream using a recipie from "The Joy of Cooking" before and failed, so I watched "The Icing man Cometh" like 4 or 5 times and read every single review to try and prepare for this, and I can definitely say I would have thrown the icing out before it set up if it wasn't for the advice of one of the reviewers who said you might need extra butter, and the advice of another reviewer that said not to give up when it looked like a soupy mess.

I'm VERY pleased with the finished product. Its very different than the buttercream you normally get in the US, but its also really good.

That being said you HAVE to take the following advice from the previous reviewers for this to work:

1 - Beat the snot out of the eggs - I beat them on high with our stand mixer for a LONG time
2 - heat the sugar and corn syrup to softball before adding
3 - Have EXTRA butter ready. It took 3 pats (1/4 stick) more than the recipie called for for mine to set up
4 - Add room temp butter
5 - Keep adding butter till its right. It will look like a horrid clumpy nasty melty mess RIGHT before it turns into buttercream frosting. You will think adding more butter is the LAST thing you should do at that point, but do it. A small amount later and bam - you got frosting.

After frosting my cake I tossed it in the fridge and let it cool down. It was good warm, but I like it even better cold. Its definitely not spreadable cold though so be sure to apply it to your cake before refridgeration.

Thanks again previous reviwers and also to AB - you the man.

I thought this recipe would turn out well as long as I clearly followed the recipe. I carefully made the recipe, even using a bit of advice from the other reviews, and came up with an extremely soft icing. Still staying optimistic despite the consistency, I tasted it to see if flavor made up for thickness. I have made many buttercream recipes and this tasted too buttery. The taste was still really buttery after I added a cup of confectioners to make it thicker and a teaspoon vanilla. I think the main problem was having the butter at room temperature, room temperature for me is seventy degrees, making the butter really soft. I'm giving it two stars because my husband did like the flavor after adding the confectioners sugar and vanilla but it was too complicated! I probably won't try again, too much work for something that doesn't work out.

I followed the recipe word for word...watching the video...with my brand new kitchenaid mixer, my new stainless steel baster, and a new inverted spatula. Total fail.

I tried a second time with all the tips in the reviews. I used only egg whites...whipped the heck out of them. I let the egg/sugar mix cool. I put the butter in so slow shadows crossed the kitchen. More fail.

I finally manged to save the third batch by adding a ton of powdered sugar to the soup. It came together with that but it that wasnt the recipe. I felt like Sandra Lee.

I was a little apprehensive about trying this recipie at first due to some of the other reviews, but I just stuck to the advice from the show and also the comments. In the end I got beautiful butterceram icing, although I did find a pinch of salt and vanilla extract helps round out the flavor.

Saw this on Good Eats last night and felt compelled to try.I used homemade corn syrup with white sugar.The egg mixture with corn syrup and butter never whipped up to a thick frosting.Currently, it is in the freezer trying to firm up.Very disappointed Food Network showcased a recipe with raw eggs for a buttercream recipe.There are other ways to make buttercream without eggs especially uncooked.Please refrain from this recipe as raw eggs are very dangerous for you,your family,friends and even customers trying your buttercream on cakes or cupcakes.Educate yourselves on samonellosis.It's worth the time.
http://www.ers.usda.gov/publications/foodreview/jan1997/jan97d.pdf

Mr. Brown,
I have watched you religiously. Yes, you've taught me to think and make great foods. Unfortunately, I watch you for technique and information.

Once again, your recipe has let me down. I won't even get into the whole cinnamon roll debacle.

However, I'm addressing this to you in hopes that you actually read this.

The flavor of the butter soup was sublime. It was carmel-ly and oh-so light on the sugars.

I watched your show at least three times - made all the prep - cooked my sugars... only to find that the sugars resembled the beginnings of tootsie rolls... so I re-made it... wasting the rest of my dark corn syrup, began slowing incorporating into my eggs... so far so good - then as I slowly added my butter I could actually SEE the mixture deflate slowly... I perservered only to end up with a soupy (albeit delicious) mess.

I beseech you to re-tape this show and (assume we haven't watched any previous episodes, i.e. carmelezation, etc.) present it in a way that I can re-create your fluffy loveliness.

Yours Truly,
Just Another Mom in Cumming Georgia

As written the recipe wont work. It was a difficult rescue, but i managed to pull it together after refrigerating the "butter soup" over night and then adding another 4 oz of butter, slowly. To my dismay, it first collapsed and resembled oatmeal, but as I continued beating and adding more butter, it very suddenly came together. I also added 2 tsp of vanilla extract, as the recipe has no flavoring whatsoever.

I frosted a dark chocolate torte with this, then refrigerated it for 2 hours. I then melted some dark belgian chocolate and drizzled it over the top of the torte. My family loved it and asked me to make it again, but I cringe at the thought. Four eggs and a pound of butter is a terrible thing to waste on a recipe that is so finicky. I will follow some other folk's suggestions, of cooking the sugars to the soft ball stage, whipping the eggs to the ribbon stage, and letting the egg/sugar mixture cool to room temp before adding the butter. I will also continue to add the vanilla extract. Without it, the buttercream was very bland. It's not as sweet as a typical american frosting, which was refreshing to me. You cannot beat this frosting for buttery smoothness, but the difficulty in making it is almost not worth the effort.
Don't make this recipe as it will fail.

Made the buttercream and it turned out ok. For those people who said it turned into a soupy mess, that may have been because the mixture was still too warm when you added the butter. To fix this you can add more butter a little at a time until it comes together, you do have to let the mixer go for a while then it will come together, or use butter that is slightly cooler if the sugar mixture is still warm. As for it being yellow, that is partially because it uses whole eggs and because of the butter.
If you cook to soft ball stage (238 to 242 degrees F) on Candy thermomter.  It will turn out beautiful and I will never make an american buttercream again.

I watched the show re-read the recipe and tried over and over again, with the same result, a soupy buttery mess. I had fluffy eggs, hot sugar, cooled off the egg sugar mixture and spent 30 minutes slowly adding butter only to fall into complete disaster with the last few slices of butter. I love the show and had great hopes for this recipe and am very sorely dissapointed.

I tried so many diffrent things with this recipe, All I got was eggy sugary buttery soup! I nomaly love Good eats and I try many of the recipies but I do not know how he is doiing it but you can NOT get the sugar in the bowl with the bulb baster WITHOUT it hitting the bowl or whisk all you get is a big mess. I would say to anyone who wants to try this DONT do it try another recipie some are very good and much better then this one! I wish I could get my money back.

PS. I thought I was the only one that this happened to im glad im not the only disapointed viewer!

I tried this recipe 4 times, and while the crud I got at the end was tasty, you could definitely not frost a cake with it.

Alton has never let me down, so let me tell you, I was traumatized :)

I found an excellent italian buttercream recipe online (which I probably can't link to here), that uses a candy thermometer, sugar syrup (no ruining of your turkey baster required - you just dump it right into the meringue in your mixer) egg whites only, and more butter. That one turned out perfectly the first try.

I was very apprehensive about trying this frosting given the reviews it has received. I followed the suggestions made below however, and it turned out beautifully!

It needs patience with some of the steps as said before. The frosting "collapses" when you first add the butter and I looked at it with horror for a while but after sticking with it the results were great! It is rich and creamy but tastes light and fluffy.

Note: this is not your typical American style frosting, it is not sugary and overly sweet. Which is perfect for my taste but may not be what you are expecting. Also I have to say the color is a bit odd.

I made my batch with cheap supermarket brand butter, still worked so the premium butter suggestion must be included for flavor. It's good to know that you can skimp on the expensive ingredients especially if the recipe is hit or miss.

Thanks AB!

i made this icing 5 times thinking it was me! this topic should be banned from the show because it does not work!!!! how disappointing!!! what trick is he using and not showing us!!!! don't even try receipe!!!!!!waste of time effort and money!!!!

Man what a God awful waste!! Can you guys send me $5.00 for my butter and eggs??! How pathetc! I am wondering if you're supposed to use egg whites instead of the whole egg, because who makes YELLOW buttercream frosting?
What a mess, and a COMPLETE waste!

A miss for AB. I'm a HUGE fan of him and his recipes. I use many of them quite frequently (overnight oats, chewy choco chip cookie, coq au van, all his brining recipes, refrigerator pickles, and so on)

A big disapointment.

The recipe is flawed. Using a kitchen aid, which I'm sure most of us do, there is no way to get the molten sugar in the bowl without it hitting either the bowl or whisk.

You are left with a soupy mess with chunks of hardened candy which is AWFUL to clean.

I've read all the reviews, I followed all the directions, and I whipped it, chilled it, and whipped it again.  It's still way too soft to stay on top of my cupcakes.  Alas, Alton, this is only the second time a recipe has gone astray (damn you christmas cookies!), so I will remain faithful.  But from now on I will stick with the slightly gross, but highly reliable shortening/butter/powdered sugar recipe.

This is the first time Alton has let me down. I followed the instructions and the tips in the other reviews to the letter and it still took a pound of confectioners' sugar to resurrect this soupy distaster into something useable.

This recipe tastes absolutely amazing (I added a tablespoon of vanilla extract) but it takes a very very long time to become firm...using a kitchen aide mixer it took almost 15 minutes...it also doesn't stay firm for too long without refridgeration.  To sum it up, the taste is great but it's not practical to use to ice a cake.

After following the step by step recipe, and ending up with butter soup, I read the collection of reviews for help.  What the key to success was "beating the snot out of the eggs, to very light and fluffy ribbons (from a 2006 review) then slowing adding the sugar mix, letting that cool completely before adding the "room temp"! butter at a pace slower than a snail. The end result was a great buttercream, that I then added a cooled, melted chocolate sauce(semi-sweat bits, vanilla, and water)to make a yummy chocolate buttercream, with coconut and fresh strawberries on top of a yellow cake.  A great birthday cake emerged!

This was my first foray into frosting land, and although I'm not entirely happy with the result (a little too light, and there are itty bitty pools of butter every where) I know what I did wrong. If you attempt this recipe, make sure that you beat the tar out of the eggs, they need to be at ribbon stage. You also need to slowly pour the sugar very close to the beater, or it cools too quickly and turns into a taffy like that won't mix out. I think my eggs/sugar was a little too warm, which melted the butter and caused the pooling. The flavor is very good and works well with ABs 'Golden Cake' recipe.

We tried this recipie 2 times both times failing! We even watched the episode. We are alton fans but this was a huge dissapointment. At first it looked fine then it decreased about half the size and looked beady. It was an expencive mistake!!!!

This frosting is amazing.  The first time I made it, I did not have any dark corn syrup and made it with light.  Soggy & runny.  The second time I made it with dark corn syrup and it worked beautifully.  I did find that it also works with light corn syrup if You substitue 1/2 c. brown sugar for the granulated. If you're like me, and you think of buttercream as being really sweet, this recipe is NOT for you.

If you got a yellow soupy mess your first time (as I did), this is what I you have to do.
*Dig out your candy thermometer and be sure your sougar mixture is soft ball stage.
*Use ONLY the egg WHITES, and beat them until they are really stiff.
*Make sure you beat the egg whites and sugar mixture on low until it is completely cool.
*If you want a whiter icing use light corn syrup instead of dark they are completely the same.
*Be VERY patient with the butter.
-Do this and you'll get a really great icing that is absolutely Good Eats!

I love Alton, so it's not easy to criticize, but this recipe is deceitful. If you don't watch the show from which it came, you are in danger of creating buttercream the consistency of cake batter. What needs to be added to the written version is this: whip the eggs until VERY fluffy, until ribbons form and they have at least doubled in volume. Also, the sugar mixture must be cooked beyond a mere boil. As the show says, the sugar should be cooked until large bubbles begin to form. My sugar boiled quickly, and I was misled by the recipe. Not having cooked enough water from the sugar, nor beaten the eggs enough, my frosting never thickened. It was a disaster. Don't make my mistakes!

Oh, and the whole turkey baster thing is not necessary.

Ok,I love Alton, he is my hero. I also have made true butter creams similar to this many times. They all present their moments of self doubt, but this one has the wrong proportions. I followed the directions exactly...and this is similar to other buttercreams I have been successful with (they were not whole egg recipes, which is why I tried this one) and I ended up with a buttery syrup. So before I through the mess out, I looked on the internet, checked my other butter cream recipes and checked out my CIA reference cook book. This recipe calls for less than half the butter per egg that any of the others did. By adding more butter (figure at least doubling it or more likely increasing it by 1.5 times)this recipe will turn out just fine. It won't be greasy or buttery (its very glossy and wet looking it too warm, but all butter creams do this). Even after I gave up on this recipe, and had set it a side for an hour or two, I was able to back and add the extra butter and revive it!
I think they just goofed up here.

I read all the reviews and tips before making this buttercream.  I also looked up similiar recipes and noticed they had the same procedure.  Mix the sugar & water/corn syrup and boil until it's at the ball stage.  Then slowly mix with the egg mixture.  Then add butter slowly and mix for a very long time.  I made sure my sugar & egg mixture was cool before I started adding the butter as I didn't want it to melt into "butter soup".  As I started adding the butter I got a little impatient and it started looking like chunks.  I managed to save it by putting the bowl in a warm water bathe and mixing at the same time.  It came out really smooth, satiny, and light.  I realized buttercream is very tempermental and that's why in the Cupcake factory or Magnolia bakery (where they use buttercream frosting), keep their cakes in the fridge.  If they weren't, the buttercream would be melting.

After *a lot* of mixing the icing finally came together well enough to stick to a cake (I made a simple devils food cake).  I added 1 tablespoon of instant coffee dissolved in the least water that would work - maybe a teaspoon.  The coffee flavor was perfect for the chocolate cake.  Overnight in the fridge did the trick to set up the icing well enough to make the whole thing presentable.  One of my guests actually went to find the cake platter in the kitched to lick off the rest of the icing.  So, a huge hit, but I'm glad I decided to make it the day before!
